citeinfo.origin: Grebmeier, J.M., L.W. Cooper, and M.L. Guarinello.
Chesapeake Biological Laboratory, University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science
citeinfo.title: Epibenthos Survey of the Bering Sea (B57)

descript.abstract:
These data are part of a study detailed in Epibenthos Survey of the Bering Sea, NPRB Project B-57 Final Report.
The study area ranged from St Lawrence Island to south of St Matthew and Nuniavak Islands (north of 59N). Data were collected from March-May 2008.This Access database includes all summary data records from our analysis of underwater video including abiotic and biotic habitat descriptions, brittle and sea star abundance values, sediment topography values, and all non-video (i.e., grab sample) generated data. The database was also used in creating maps in ArcMap and associated GDB files are found in this file.
The Excel file includes results of all video analyses. Data not contained in the Access database includes details of identified fauna (GeneralDescrip worksheet) and counts (Counts Track worksheet) for each station from qualitative analysis, image still frame analysis results for 19 sites. Includes general descriptions of substrate, functional groups, classes/species that make up these groups, and additional features of note.
descript.purpose: Our primary objective was to acquire and use underwater benthic video data for qualitative and quantitative epibenthic habitat characterization in the Bering Sea. The results also supplement traditional infaunal community data collections made during the two research cruises.

spdom.descgeog: Data encompasses the polynya area south of St. Lawerence Is. and areas west of St. Matthew Is. and between St. Matthew Is and Nunivak Is.

browse.browsed: Figure 1. Map of video stations for HLY0801 and HLY0802 in the Bering Sea, 2008

taxonomy.taxongen: Only the most abundant fauna are noted here in taxonomy, Refer to the associated Excel file for other epifauna observed during our study.

cntperp.cntorg: Chesapeake Biological Laboratory, University of Maryland Center for Environmental Scinece

tool.tooldesc: PRIMER v6- used for multivariate data analysis and clustering
iMovie used for editing video files
Adobe Photoshop used for analyzing still frame images

method.methdesc: We used a benthic camera system in 2008 to determine epibenthic community structure in the BEST-BSIERP study area (Figure 1) during cruises HLY0801 and HLY0802. The benthic camera system was a stand-alone system consisting of a surface-held video camera connected by electronic cable to a camera lens, lights, and laser pointers, all enclosed in a small metal cage, that allows independent deployment and fine control for real-time benthic imaging measurements.

procstep.procdesc: We are analyzing the digital video imagery to determine epifaunal abundance and composition and compare these to epifaunal-size associated biomass data from previous trawling efforts to convert abundance and size from our camera survey to a rough estimate of biomass over a specific surface area.

cntperp.cntorg: University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science, Chesapeake Biological Laboratory

procstep.procdesc: New metadata record established for B57 Grebmeier. Prepared from orignial filename B57 Meta data video.doc and AMIS project information. Name: B57_Grebmeier_epibenthic.xml, renamed B57_Grebmeier.xml
Metadata record EpibenthosB57.xml received by AOOS from PI, and combined with B57_Grebmeier.xml

overview.eaover:
HLY0801.02_Video.xls:
Data sheets: Data_Stills analysis of still frames captured from video footage //Counts_Track counts of larger fauna, those not overly abundant,. Stills not as likely to represent abundance (e.g., spider crabs, starfish) //Gen_Descrip general habitat description from video notes (i.e., from watching video)

This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with the data. The NPRB shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.
